grammary.title: Direct and reported speech
grammary.content:
Direct speech -------------------------------------------------------------------
Używamy gdy cytujemy kogoś, przytaczamy czyjeś słowa:
"I'll be late home tommorrow", Bob SAID.
===================================================================
Reported speech -------------------------------------------------------------------
Gdy relacjonujemy co ktoś powiedział, ale nie używamy jego dokładnych słów. Wtedy możemy to zrobić w następujący sposób:
----------------------------- 1. Reporting statements -----------------------------
Zmiana czasu o jeden wstecz: (D - direct / R - reported)
Present simple: D: "I'm a nurse", she said. R: She said she was a nurse. //Past Simple
Present continuous: D: "I'm not going", she said. R: She said she was not going. //Past Simple Continuous
Past simple: D: "Tomy did it", she said. R: She said Tomy had done it. //Past Perfect
Present Perfect: D: "I haven't read it", she said. R: She said she had not read it.
Past continuous: D: "I was lying", he said. R: He said he had been lying. //Past Perfect Continuous
Will future: D: "I will get it", she said. R: She said she would get it. //Would
Can: D: "I can speak French", he said. R: He said he could speak French. //Could
May: D: "I may be late", she said. R: She said she might be late. //Might
Must: D: "I must go", he said. R: He said he had to go. //Had to
Uwaga: PAST PERFECT i modale (might, ought to, could, should i would) nie zmieniają sie w REPORTED SPEACH.
----------------------------------------- 2. Changes in time and place references -----------------------------------------
Gdy relacjonujemy zmianie ulega czas i miejsce:
Direct / Reported
today / that day tomorrow / the next day, the following day yesterday / the previous day, the day before two days ago / two days before, two days earlier now / then here / there come / go
Gdy relacjonujemy coś w ten sam dzień oczywiście czas się nie zmienia.
Marie phoned on Sunday. Marie phoned yesterday. (Said on Monday) He said that Marie had phone two days ago. (said on Tuesday)
----------------------------------------- 3. Reporting question -----------------------------------------
Gdy relacjonujemy pytanie, tak jak poprzednio cofamy o jeden czas, zmieniamy czas i miejsce
Jeśli pytanie było skonstruowane za pomocą inwersji ze słówkiem DO, DOES, DID to dodatkowo dodajemy słówko IF/WHETHER i uwaga - zdanie zostawiamy tak jak było - nie ma inwersji !
Do you understand? He asked me IF/WHETHER I understood?
Did you see it? He asked her If she had seen it?
Jeśli zdanie nie było tworzone przez inwersję to zostaje słówko pytające i zdanie bez inwersji!
When are you arriving? He asked me when I was arriving?
Zamiast ASKED można użyć WANTED TO KNOW IF.
Mr Jones wanted to know if I was enjoying myself.
----------------------------------------- 4. Reporting advice, commands, requests nd warnings -----------------------------------------
Advice: D: "You really should stop!" R: She advised me to stop.
Command: D: "Don't interrupt me!" R: He told me not to interrupt him.
Request: * "Could you close the door please?" She asked me to close the door.
Warning: ** "If you tell anyone, I'll ...! She warned me not to tell anyone
* Uwaga, w tym przypadku też mamy doczynienia z pytaniem ale kontekst jest inny:
"Can you remind me, please?" (request) He asked me to remind him.
"Can you come tomorrow?" (question) She asked me if I could come the next day.
** Uwaga, w tym przypadku też struktura zmienia się w zależności od kontekstu:
Come on! Hurry up! (command) She told us to hurry up.
"It doesn't start till eight" (statement) He told us it didn't start until eight.
----------------------------------------- 5. Reporting suggestions -----------------------------------------
D: Let's stay in.
R: She suggested that we (should) stay in. R: She suggested that we stayed in. R: She suggested staying in.
Uwaga: nie możemy użyć bezokolicznika po suggest (ponieważ jest to gerund).

grammary.title: SO / SUCH
grammary.content:
Używamy SO lub SUCH aby zwrócić na coś szczególną uwagę:
Everyone was SO friendly. They were SUCH friendly people.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
SO używamy z:
- przymiotnikami i przysłówkami:
Our journey was SO QUICK. Our journey went SO QUICKLY.
- much/little + (niepoliczalne rzeczowniki):
We had SO MUCH TIME. She had SO LITTLE MONEY left.
- many/few + (mnogie policzalne rzeczowniki):
SO MANY PEOPLE applied for that job. There were SO FEW JOBS available
===================================================================
SUCH używamy z
- a + adj. + pojedyńczy rzeczownik
We saw SUCH A GOOD FILM.
- adj. + mnogie policzalne rzeczowniki / niepoliczalne rzeczowniki
Everyone was wearing SUCH BRIGHT CLOTHES. We had SUCH DREADFUL WEATHER on our holiday.
- a lot (of ...) + mnogie policzalne rzeczowniki / niepoliczalne rzeczowniki
We had SUCH A LOT OF THING to do. He won SUCH A LOT OF MONEY.
